skills.name: Multiplication law of indices with positive fractional powers and the same base number
Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number
Division law of indices with negative integer powers and the same base number
Calculate questions involving the power law of indices with positive integer powers
Calculate questions involving the power law of indices with negative integer powers

explanations.A: When we have the same base number and we multiply, we add the powers. This gives 2¹ = 2
explanations.B: I think you added the 1 and 2 in the numerators of the powers and did 2³. What do you get when you add the fractions in the powers? What does this simplify to?
explanations.C: I think you multiplied the powers. When we multiply numbers with the same base number we add the powers.
explanations.D: I think you subtracted the powers. When we multiply numbers with the same base number we add the powers.

explanations.A: Just check your addition of the fractions in the powers. We add the numerators but the denominators don't change.
explanations.B: When we have the same base number and we multiply, we add the powers. This gives 4 to the power of 4/2 = 2. So we have 4² = 16.
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied the first 4 by 1/2 and the second 4 by 3/2 and then multiplied these numbers together. Powers are different to multiplication. Try the sum with some easier powers and see if you can spot a link
explanations.D: I think you have added the powers correctly, but you multiplied the base number too. Remember the base should stay the same

explanations.A: I think you have subtracted the powers the wrong way round.
explanations.B: When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide. 3 - 4 = -1, so we have 2^-1
explanations.C: I think you have divided the powers. When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide
explanations.D: I think you have made a mistake with your subtraction. Start at 3 and then go down 4. Where do you end up?

explanations.A: I think you have divided the powers. When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide
explanations.B: I think you have subtracted the powers the wrong way round.
explanations.C: I think you have divided the base number. This stays the same as the power is telling us how many copies of the base number we have
explanations.D: When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide. 6 - 2 = 4, so we have 5⁴.

explanations.A: When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide. -3 - -4 = -3 + 4 = 1, so we have 2¹ = 2.
explanations.B: I think you have subtracted the powers the wrong way round.
explanations.C: I think you have divided the powers. When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide
explanations.D: I think you made a mistake with the subtraction. Remember subtracting a negative is the same as adding a positive.

explanations.A: I think you forgot to take into account the negative signs. Remember subtracting a negative is the same as adding a positive.
explanations.B: I think you made a mistake with the subtraction. Remember subtracting a negative is the same as adding a positive.
explanations.C: When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide. -7 - -3 = -7 + 3 = -4, so we have 3^-4
explanations.D: I think you have divided the powers. When we have the same base we subtract the powers when we divide

explanations.A: I think you multiplied the numbers inside the bracket. This question is saying that we have 5 copies of 2 cubed multiplied together. How many copies of 2 is this?
explanations.B: I think you multiplied the 2 by the 5. This question is saying that we have 5 copies of 2 cubed multiplied together. How many copies of 2 is this?
explanations.C: We have 5 copies of 2 cubed multiplied together. That means we have 15 copies of 2, so it is 2¹⁵. We can just multiply the powers together in this question
explanations.D: I think you added the powers. This question is saying that we have 5 copies of 2 cubed multiplied together. How many copies of 2 is this?

explanations.A: I think you added the powers. This question is saying that we have 2 copies of 7 to the power of 5, all multiplied together. How many copies of 7 is this?
explanations.B: I think you squared the 7 and squared the 5. This question is saying that we have 2 copies of 7 to the power of 5, all multiplied together. How many copies of 7 is this?
explanations.C: I think you squared the base number. This question is saying that we have 2 copies of 7 to the power of 5, all multiplied together. How many copies of 7 is this?
explanations.D: We have 2 copies of 7 to the power of 5, all multiplied together. This means we have 10 copies of 7 in total, so 7¹⁰. In this question we can just multiply the powers.

explanations.A: Just be careful with your negatives here.
explanations.B: I think you added the powers, but we use this when we are multiplying. What operation do we use on the powers when we are raising to a power?
explanations.C: Here we need to multiply the powers. -3 x -5 = 15, so we have 2¹⁵.
explanations.D: I think you added the powers and made an error with the negatives. We add powers when we are multiplying. What operation do we use on the powers when we are raising to a power?

explanations.A: Just be careful with your negatives here.
explanations.B: Here we need to multiply the powers. -3 x -4 = 12, so we have 3¹².
explanations.C: I think you did 3³ as well as multiplying the powers. Remember the powers are telling us about how many copies of 3 we have, so the base doesn't change
explanations.D: This is equivalent to 3^(-12), just be careful with your negatives.
